evidence.pdf_reference: Metal clusters catalyst embedded in semiconductors is the key factor for an efficient photocatalyst toward photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.However, developing a simple method to synthesize such photocatalyst with these features has remained challenging.Herein, a rational one-step synthesis of cobalt clusters embedded in g-C 3 N 4 layers is developed for an enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.The tiny cobalt clusters are embedded into the g-C 3 N 4 structure and stabilized through the interaction with NH 2

optimized conditions, representative C 3 N 4 -0.5CoOx exhibits the very high CO generation rate of 2.6 lmol.hA1 .Its apparent quantum yield of 3.2 at 420 nm and 1.0 at 460 nm, which is one of the highest values reported so far.The finding offers new opportunities for designing metal clusters catalysts toward photocatalytic CO 2 reduction based on the judicious use of the metal complex.

homogeneous distribution of C and N over the entire selected area.Moreover, the fine dispersion of Co is indicated by the tiny spots of Co, as shown in Fig. 3c. The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under solar light irradiation was performed to investigate the correlation between the cobalt loadings and photocatalytic activity (Fig. 4a).The optimized amount (5 mg) of C 3 N 4 -0.5CoOx photocatalyst was used since it produced the highest amount of CO and enhanced the selectivity toward the CO product (Fig.

(150 W Xe lamp) with 10 s light onoff cycle.The electrolyte was purged with Argon for 20 min before any photoelectrochemical measurements. In a typical photocatalytic reaction, a specific amount of photocatalyst was dispersed in a mixture of 9 ml acetonitrile, and 1 ml triethanolamine (TEOA) in a 40 ml quartz test tube.Before photocatalytic testing, the reaction solution was bubbled with CO 2 (99.9,Praxair) in the dark for 20 min and then sealed with a rubber septum.The reaction was then irradiated with

next three consecutive steps involve the proton-coupled electron-transfer process to form CO and regenerate Co II species (eq.2-4).The photogenerated hole is consumed equivalently by the sacrificial agent TEOA (eq.5-6) 39.Note that TEOA can act as both electron donor and proton donor in the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction process (eq.7).

product was formed when the reaction was carried out in the dark or without a photocatalyst, revealing that the reduction of CO 2 is really driven by photocatalyst and light irradiation.Moreover, in the case when argon was used instead of CO 2 , no CO was detected, validated that the formation of CO was indeed originated from the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.Also, CO was not generated in the absence of TEOA, revealing that TEOA works as a sacrificial agent for the photocatalytic CO 2

with the irradiation time, reaching a maximum of 13.3 lmol in 8 h.Although the rate of H 2 generation also increases with time, the selectivity for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction is still nearly 90 after 8 h.These results prove that the cobalt clusters incorporated in the g-C 3 N 4 structure act as the active sites for the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction. as evidenced by the smaller semicircle arc at the given frequency range.The lower charge-transfer resistance in C 3 N 4 -0.5CoOx provides a faster electron transfer, which is beneficial for efficient separation of electron-hole pairs during the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.Both the higher photocurrent response and lower charge-transport resistance further validated the superior photocatalytic properties of the C 3 N 4 -0.5CoOx system.A plausible five-step reaction mechanism for photocatalytic CO 2
